data.name: BoquetAroma
data.value: When assessing wine, the term "aroma" is used to describe the smell of the grape varietals and the smells of the fermentation process. The term "bouquet" is used to describe the smell of the complete, aged wine.

data.name: ChardonnayButter
data.value: The buttery flavor found in some Chardonnay is due to the malolactic fermentation that converts malic acid into lactic acid. This forms "diacetyl", the same compound found in artificial butter flavoring.

data.name: ChardonnayGrape
data.value: Airén and Chardonnay are the two most widely planted white grape varietals in the world.

data.name: ChillWhiteQuicker
data.value: The next time you need to chill white wine fast use a bucket of ice water and add salt to the mixture to lower the freezing point.

data.name: Dom
data.value: Dom Pérignon is a vintage champagne that is named after a Benedictine monk who pioneered many winemaking techniques and who is often (perhaps incorrectly) attributed as being the inventor of champagne.

data.name: Muselet
data.value: A "muselet" is a wire cage that secures the cork to the top of a champagne bottle. The name comes from the French word museler "to muzzle".

data.name: NumberOfGrapes
data.value: It takes a cluster of approximately 75 grapes to produce just one glass of white wine.

data.name: Oenophobia
data.value: There are people who suffer fear or anxiety related to wine. The condition is known as oenophobia.

data.name: RedGrapes
data.value: Not all white wine is made from white grapes. Grapes used to make white wine can range from orange and pink to dark red and black. For example Pinot Grigio is made from dark purple grapes.

data.name: RemoveStains
data.value: It is possible to use white wine to remove red wine stains, especially if applied shortly after the spill. Try it out in a pinch, but don't use too much!

data.name: WhiteChangeColour
data.value: As white wine ages, it's color will change, going from a lighter golden color to a vibrant, darker gold. Aged long enough, white wine may become an almost brown, tea like color.

data.name: WhiteStorageTannins
data.value: White wines spend less time in contact with grape skins than red wines, which is why whites contain less tannins and cannot be stored as long (since the skins impart natural preservatives into the wine).

data.name: WhiteWineExpire
data.value: Most white wines expire faster than reds. However, some white wines can be aged quite long due to their high acidity. High quality White Bordeauxs and German Rieslings can develop with age for decades.

data.name: WhiteWineHealth
data.value: Although white wine doesn't contain some of the beneficial compounds found in red wine, many studies have shown white wine to have similar health benefits as red (when consumed in moderation).

data.name: WhiteWineSweetness
data.value: White wine ranges in sweetness from very dry to very sweet. The driest whites include Pinot Grigio, Albariño, and Grenache Blanc. The sweetest include Ice Wine, White Port, and Vin Santo.
